No actual security risks were found - the 'external_commands' were Python code examples in markdown, and 'weak cryptographic algorithms' were misidentified words like 'digestion'. This is a legitimate digital pathology library with no malicious functionality.

content.user_title: Process whole slide images for digital pathology
content.value_statement: Histolab automates tissue detection and tile extraction from gigapixel whole slide images. It processes WSI files to extract informative tiles for deep learning pipelines and medical research.
actual_capabilities: Extract tiles from whole slide images using random, grid, or score-based strategies
Automatically detect tissue regions and filter background artifacts
Apply image preprocessing filters for stain normalization and quality control
Visualize slides, masks, and tile locations with matplotlib integration
Handle multiple WSI formats including SVS, TIFF, and NDPI files
limitations: Designed for H&E stained images, may need customization for other stains
Requires significant memory for large WSI files at full resolution
Basic functionality compared to specialized tools like PathML for complex workflows

prompt_templates.title: Basic tile extraction
prompt_templates.scenario: Extract tiles from a single slide
prompt_templates.prompt: Load the slide at path 'slide.svs' and extract 100 random tiles of size 512x512 pixels. Save them to 'output/tiles/' directory.

prompt_templates.title: Tissue detection
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a tissue mask for my slide and visualize it. Use the BiggestTissueBoxMask to focus on the main tissue section.

prompt_templates.title: Grid extraction workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Extract tiles in a grid pattern across all tissue regions with 20% overlap. Use tissue mask to avoid background areas.

prompt_templates.title: Quality-based selection
prompt_templates.prompt: Use ScoreTiler with NucleiScorer to extract the 50 tiles with highest nuclei density. Generate a report of tile scores.

best_practices: Always preview tile locations with locate_tiles() before extraction to verify settings
Use appropriate pyramid level - level 0 for full resolution, level 1-2 for faster processing
Set tissue_percent threshold between 70-90% to balance coverage and quality
anti_patterns: Extracting all tiles at highest resolution without considering memory constraints
Using RandomTiler without setting a seed for reproducible results
Skipping tissue mask preview which may lead to extracting background tiles

faq.question: What file formats does histolab support?
faq.answer: Histolab supports common WSI formats including SVS, TIFF, NDPI, and other formats compatible with OpenSlide library.

faq.question: How do I handle slides with multiple tissue sections?
faq.answer: Use TissueMask instead of BiggestTissueBoxMask to detect all tissue regions, or create custom masks for specific ROIs.

faq.question: Can I extract tiles at multiple resolutions?
faq.answer: Yes, use the level parameter (0=full resolution, 1=half resolution, etc.) or extract hierarchically with multiple tilers.

faq.question: How do I remove pen annotations from slides?
faq.answer: Create custom filters using HSV color space to detect and exclude pen markings based on their characteristic colors.

faq.question: What's the difference between RandomTiler and GridTiler?
faq.answer: RandomTiler samples tiles randomly across tissue, good for training data. GridTiler extracts in systematic pattern for complete coverage.

faq.question: How can I speed up extraction for large datasets?
faq.answer: Use lower pyramid levels, reduce tile count, use BiggestTissueBoxMask, and enable logging to monitor progress.
